Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is implementing Mathematics Scholars 2015 (MS 2015) to enroll twenty eight (28) achieving, but financially needy incoming freshman and current students, as full-time Mathematics majors who are pursuing an associate degree in Mathematics. The goal is to increase the numbers of Mathematics scholars who enter the workforce or transfer to a university following completion of an associate degree. Project objectives include: (1) recruit, select and award eligible MS 2015 Scholars with scholarships, (2) retain MS 2015 Scholars utilizing enrichment activities including study group sessions, scholars hour, faculty mentoring, academic advising, attendance at conferences, internships, and field trips with university and industry partners, and (3) ensure Scholars enrolled in MS 2015 earn an associate degree and either secure employment with the support of the College career placement services, or pursue a baccalaureate degree with support of the College Transfer Services. Scholars also have the opportunity to gain real life experiences in STEM fields through Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU)/Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP), employer job shadowing, and internships. The project targets primarily underrepresented groups. Project results are widely disseminated to share results and emerging innovations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of four years, this project recruited and enrolled into the Mathematics Scholars 2015 program 63 unduplicated full-time academically talented but financially disadvantaged math majors attending Northeast Lakeview College, a community college in San Antonio, Texas.  Project objectives included: (1) Increasing the overall semester-to-semester Mathematics retention rate; (2) increasing the number of Mathematics majors who graduate with an associate degree or transfer to a four-year school; (3) providing robust programmatic infrastructure to ensure increasing success rates within the STEM scholars cohort; and (4) expanding and enriching learning and career placement opportunities by requiring STEM Scholars to participate in professional development activities such as career exploration, job shadowing, mentorships, internships, and research activities.

At the end of the project the average fall-to-fall Mathematics retention rate had risen from 60% to 86.5%. More than half of the participants in the program either graduated from Northeast Lakeview College or transferred to a four year institution to receive a bachelor’s degree. All but one of those students chose to major in a STEM-related field. All participants in the program attended Scholars Hour and Scholars Study Group Sessions where they were exposed to academic enrichment and STEM career exploration activities. In addition participants made presentations at state-wide Mathematics conferences.

The results from a number of the components of this program can inform efforts to retain and graduate STEM students in the larger academic community. Project findings have also advanced the understanding and knowledge of innovative teaching and learning practices for working with motivated, academically talented, low-income STEM students, particularly the influence of social integration activates on the retention of STEM students. Above all, the Mathematics Scholars 2015 project has made an important contribution to local economic development by increasing the numbers of STEM graduates who are likely to remain in the community and add to the local STEM workforce.

In addition, from fall 2011 to spring 2015, the MS2015 scholars invited numerous STEM-Field guest speakers from local companies, visited local 4-year universities and local STEM-Field companies, attended math conferences, and volunteered for various local community events.
